OLD LIBRARY—

THE NEW—an architect's sketch of the proposed new Johns Hopkins University library.

Conditions in the J.H.U. Library were called "deplorable . . .
monstrously crowded .... full
almost to the point of everflowing ... archaic ... disgusting
. . . . hardly conducive to efficiency," in interviews conducted by the News-Letter this
week.
Miss Hubbard Gives Views
Head Librarian in the Main
Reading Room, Miss Martha
Hubbard, stated, "We already
have so many books that there
is no room left on the shelves.
We have to be constantly shifting shelves around to make
room for new books. Since there
is so much of this shifting
around, it is impossible to keep
track of the location of some
books, and the heads of departments are forced to keep the
new locations in their heads.
The crowded and dirty condition of the present library are
enough to eliminate even the
very hope of efficiency, and the
arrival of every new book creates
new problems and new frustration."
New Philosophies Bring
New Problems
Miss Emily Schilpp, Assistant
Librarian and head of Technical
Services gave an additional reason for the compelling need for
new quarters for the Library:
"The Library needs to bring itself in line with the new
philosophy of education. The

The long-delayed new library
on the Homewood campus is on
the point of becoming more of a
reality, according to Wilbert
Locklin, Assistant to the President of the University.
The News-Letter, seeking the
cause of the standstill in the
plans for the.new library, which
were announeed two years ago,
interviewed Mr. John Peach,
Asst. Plant Manager, who laid
the blame for the delay on lack
of funds. Seeking the answer to
the question which has been
plaguing the University since
the announcement of numerous
grants, we inquired in the offices
of the Hopkins Fund why none -I
these grants has been used for
the Library. We were informed
that the Hopkins Fund only
raises the money and has no say
in its allocation, and were referred to Mr. Locklin.
Plans Outlined
Mr. Locklin, in an extensive
interview with a N-L reporter,
explained the answer to this
complex matter by outlining the
plans of the University, the
system for obtaining grants, and
the problems that arise in the
process.
Locklin explained that when
the "Decade of Development"
project was announced, the development program included a
great variety of projects, four of
which were given "priority"; viz..
the Children's Medical Center;

Johns Hopkins File 7 Dropped;
Abandoned After 12 Year Run

Baltimore Poll Decides
Kennedy Big Hit OnTV
A presidential poll was taken
In this city by the Social Relations Department of Johns
Hopkins under the direction of
Dr. James Coleman. The purPose of this poll was to see how
the televised convention and debates had affected the people's
thinking.
The actual polling was done
by telephone. Eight hundred
People in the Baltimore area
Were called at three different
times during the year. ,
The first call was made in
early June before the nominating conventions. At this time
28.0% favored Nixon, 49.0%
Kennedy, and 23.0% • were undetided. In the last wek of August,
after the Republican convention,
the same people were called. At
this time 3.3% of the "unde-

NEW LIBRARY

cided" switched to Nixon. This
may have been due to the fact
that the Republican convention
was fresh in the minds of the
people, and they were impressed
with Nixon's speech.
The last phase of the poll was
taken after the second KennedyNixon debate, and this found a
switch of 3.2% of the previously
undecided to Kennedy.
Because Baltimore is a naturally Democratic city, these
percentages are not a valid indication of the trends in the
country, but the trend in the
undecided vote may very well
be an indication of the trends
in the country.

director of Public Relations for
the University, stated that at its
peak "File 7" was carried by 95
stations throughout the country.
Fewer Stations
But by the first week in September, when the last program
was shown, there were less than
thirty stations carrying the series, Mr. Poole added.
During the first years of its
run "File 7" was the only show
of its kind because stations did
not have the trained staffs necessary to produce such a program.
But over the years stations acquired these staffs.
"Each station has a public
service to perform for the community," Mr. Poole stated, "but
there is only a limited amount
of time it has to give for such
public service programs.
Local Interests
"Because of these factors more
and more local stations presented
public service programs from
local colleges and universities.
When they did this, they dropped
'File 7.'
"Comparing the 200 manhours required for every half
hour program, we found that we
were not getting a return for the
time invested."

Professor Named
Winner Of Award
For Public Health
Dr. Abel Wolman, Johns
Hopkins University
professor
emeritus of sanitary engineering, today was named winner of
a special award in the field of
public health given by the Albert
and Mary Lasker Foundation
and the American Public Health
association,
Dr. Wolman will receive a
special $5,000 award and a gold
statuette, the "Winged Victory
of Samothrace," symobilizing
victory over death and disease,
The Johns Hopkins University
scientist was cited for his "distinguished contributions to public health and safety in sanitary
engineering, water supply development, and control of radiation hazards."

According to Mr. Johnson,
the foreign-language placement
tests will be abolished entirely.
Foreign language placement in
the future will depend upon the
student's score on the language
examinations of the College Entrance Examination Boards. It
was also felt that the various

"psychological" tests containing
such questions as "The Rhine is
longer than the Ohio. True or
False?" could well be done away
with.
As pertains to the other aspects of Orientation Week, the
box lunches, although highly
unpopular, will probably remain,
since they are the only practical
means of feeding so many people before the dormitory dining
halls are opened.
Any comments or suggestions
pertaining to orientation should
be submitted in writing, signed,
to the Admissions Office.

JHU-Hood Drama Group
To Discuss Play By Becket
The Hopkins-Hood Drama
Group will .meet in the Sherwood Room of Levering Hall on
Nov. 13 to discuss Samuel
Becket's Endgame. Hopkins students can obtain copies of the
play at the bookstore. Those
persons interested in the group
should contact Bob Dickens at
the "Y" office.

group. It will meet once a month
alternately at Hopkins and
Hood.
The purpose of this group is
to study the characters, ideas
and methods of contemporary
dramatists through the media
of study, dramatic reading, and
discussion.

Newspaper Column
The column "From File 7," a
project that was undertaken
when the producers of the television series realized that the
program would have to be taken
off the air, is now starting its
third year of publication.
Written on alternate weeks by
Mr. Poole and his associate
James Butler, it now appears
weekly in 170 papers in the country, all of them dailies with a
circulation of over 10,000.
In addition the United States
Information Agency distributed
the column to its 110 offices
throughout the world.

has selected the one which will

In Memoriam
It was the longest running regularly scheduled program on television; for twelve years it amazed, informed,
taught, explained, and pioneered; it carried the name of
The Johns Hopkins University into millions upon millions
of homes; it brought Lynn Poole into the chair of producer, director, actor, and wr'iter ; it was all these things,
and many more, but it's all over—Johns Hopkins File 7
has closed shop.
Pressed by that economic law of diminishing returns,
File 7 saw itself being shelved all over the country lately
to make way for local interest educational programs. It
was becoming harder and harder for professors and
teachers to spare the time to help produce the kind of
quality shows typical to File 7.
If it be so, let this be a black and white memorial to
a fine job, well done. We are quite sure that this same
feeling is echoed by all those who grabbed the spark
offered to them by the program, and with it lighted the
tamp of higher learning.
There have been many 'thrilling' experiences connected with the program, but for Lynn Poole his proudest
was the year that freshmen avidly recalled the Hopkins
program, and the interest it generated, from their gradeschool days.

One Down—Two To Go
The Student Council jumped over the 2.3 minimum
average at its meeting this week, and landed on a significant motion: that members of the Student Council will be
subject to the same academic requirements as the executives of all other Hopkins organizations. In effect, this
means, assuming the 2.3 is retained, that just to be a
member of the council a man must hold an average of 2.3
—required of the officers of all other organizations, but
not of their members. A good step in the right direction!
Next: the 2.3 average—to keep in its present form
or to alter it; then: the enforcement of the requirement,
a problem which will bring in the questions of "waivers"
and whether the SAC is the proper organization to grant
them.

Ilue Key
The Director of Admissions at Johns Hopkins University, Robert Bilgrave, cites the example of the "topnotch physics student who almost came to Hopkins." He
visited JHU one day, received his interview, then was
handed a map of the campus and sent on his way. He
also visited M.I.T. There he was met by some of that
school's undergraduates who gave him a tour, answered
his questions, and made him feel completely welcome—
and wanted. Though prior to his trips he had indicated
preference for Hopkins, he wound at M.I.T.

AHA, ME PROUD BEAUTY!!!

Pro Arte

German Music At Levering
Delta Phi Alpha, the German
honor society on the Johns
Hopkins campus, inaugurated its
activities of the year on Tuesday evening with a recorded
concert of German vocal music
from medieval times through
Bach. The concert was held at
Levering Hall and was in coordination with the German
club at Goucher College. This is
the first in a series of three
concerts in three consecutive
weeks that will attempt to trace
the development of the German
tongue through music. Next
Tuesday, the concert will include
the vocal music of the- classic
and romantic German composers. The third concert will
be devoted to late romantic
leider through the works of
Schoenberg,
Hindemith
and
modern German Composers.
Tuesday evening's concert began with a medieval song withaccompaniment,
iated

music for pleasure, the program

chosen seemed quite appropriate. Not only did it illustrate
the evolution of medieval German music, it was also very
pleasing to the ear. Anyone with
an interest in classical German
music will probably find the next
two concerts much to his liking.
Next week the program will feature music of, Beethoven and
Mozart. Delta Phi Alpha cordially invites all those interested to
attend the next two concerts.

By MIKE KOPPISCH
This year's freshman play,
"Love Rides the Rails," was an
abrupt departure from plays of
this sort presented in the past.
This comedy-melodrama-audience participation fiasco, under
the direction of Nick Bonacker
and Dennis Donahue, provided
the audience with as much oppOrtunity to display its talent
as it did the actors. In fact,
there were several cries from
the pit which met with as much
approval as certain parts of the
actual production.
As for talent, this reviewer is
forced to take the side of the
villains. Of course, it must also
be considered that these characterizations lent themselves to
humor much more readily than
those of the fair Prudence Hopewell and the "dry" Truman
Pendennis. Peter Grossman, who
played the moustached, caped
villain, Simon Darkway, carried out his role in a classic
manner. However, whether or
not he inspired any hate in the
audience is a matter left open to
debate. His "ever-scratching"
and imbecilic stooge Dirk Sneath
was very ably portrayed by Ed
Shiller.
Nancy Monroe as the ingenuous Miss Prudence Hopewell
evoked much applause from the
audience when, in the end of
the play, she was forced to remove her skirt and reveal her
bloomers in the presence of
gentlemen. The widow Hopewell
was also well characterized by
Barbara MacNamara. She provided much audience participation in the form of an "Amen"
after every mention of her dear
departed husband—Amen.
I found Joanne Winks' performance as the seductive Carlotta
Cortez very convincing. The
milk-sop, Truman Pendennis
and his naive playmate, Harold
Standfast, played by David
Munro and John Gunderson respectively, were not as convincing as they might have been.
A word must also be said for
David Hegen, who was responsible for the melodious tones
which emanated from a piano
which, I hope, has seen better
days. Many people do not realize
the true importance of music to
a show such as this. Without
musical accompaniment, this
show's success would have been
in possible jeopardy.
The purpose of the freshmen
play has always been to heighten spirit within the class. It has
therefore never been a serious
venture and should not be regarded as such. From the reaction of the audience, I would
say that this goal was fairly
well achieved.

"HOME SWEET HOMECOMING"
A great number of people have been asking me lately, "What
Is Homecoming?" but I have been so busy trying to find out
why my new sports car leaks that I haven't had time to answer.
I am now pleased to report that I finally discovered why my
sports car leaks—I have been driving it upside down—and so
I am ready today to turn my attention to Homecoming.
Let's begin with definitions. Homecoming is a weekend when
old grads return to their alma maters to watch a football game,
visit old classrooms and dormitories and inspect each other's
bald spots.
The weekend is marked by the singing of old songs, the slapping of old backs and the frequent exchange of such greetings
as "Harry,'you old polecat!" or "Harry, you old porcupine!"
or "Harry, you old rooster!" or "Harry, you old wombat!"
As you can see, all old grads are named Harry.
It is not just old grads who behave with such liveliness during
Homecoming; the faculty also comports itself with unaccustomed animation. Teachers laugh and smile and pound backs
and keep shouting "Harry,you old Airedale!" This unscholarly
behavior is carried on in the hope that old grads, in a transport
of bonhomie will endow a new geology building.
The old grads, however; are seldom seduced. By game time
on Saturday their backs are so sore, their eyeballs so eroded,
their extremities so frayed, that it is impossible to get a kind
word out of them, much less a new geology building.

Even the football game does not improve their tempers.
!'llmmph!" they snort as the home team completes a 101-yard
march to a touchdown."Do you call that football? Why, back
in my day, they'd have been over on the first down! By
George, football was football in those days—not this nambypamby girls' game that passes for football today! Take a look
at that bench-50 substitutes sitting there. Why, in my day,
there were 11 men on a team and that was it. When you broke
a leg, they slapped a piece of tape on it and you went right back
in. Why, I remember the big game against State. Harry Sigafoos, our star quarterback, was killed in the third quarter. I
mean, he was pronounced dead. But did that stop old Harry?
Not on your tintype! Back in he went and kicked the winning
drop kick in the last four seconds of play, dead as he was. Back
in my day, they played football, by George!"
Everything,say the old grads, was better back in their day—
everything except one. Even the most unreconstructed of the
old grads has to admit that back in his day they never had a
smoke like Marlboro—never a cigarette with such a lot to like
—never a filter so easy drawing, a flavor so mild yet hearty, so
abundant, so bountiful—never a choice of flip-top box or soft
pack.
So old grads, young grads, and undergrads, why don't you
settle back and have a full-flavored smoke? Try Marlboro, the
filtered cigarette with the unfiltered taste, and Homecoming
will be a happy occasion and the sun will shine and the air will
be filled with the murmur of wings and no man's hand will be
raised against you.

NAME: John Hulse AGE: 27 MAJOR: Bus. Adm.'
PRESENT JOB: Telephone Manager, Sioux City,Iowa
When John Hulse was a senior at the U. of
South Dakota, he had his own set of "do's" and
"don'ts." Don't become a mere cipher on somebody's payroll. Don't sit on the shelf waiting for
your first taste of responsibility. Do get a job
where you have a chance to show your stuff
right from the start. Do the job.
John knew his B.S. in Business Administration could lead him into almost any field. He
chose the telephone business and joined Northwestern Bell.
One of his first assignments: streamlining operating procedures for the telephone offices of Iowa's
five largest cities. In this work John showed
good judgment and sound organizing ability.
Today he is Telephone Manager of Sioux
City, Iowa.

Besides managing day-to-day operations,
helping plan tomorrow's telephone growth is
an important part of John's job. A typical example is the work he does with the Sioux City
Industrial Development Association. In this role,
he's the answer man on projecting, planning and
supplying the communications needs of new industry. He's shown above with Bob Sweeney,
manager of the Sioux City Chamber of Commerce.
"You must always be thinking of the future
in this business," John says. "We have to stay
ahead. I think a man who has something to offer
this outfit won't have a minute's worry about
what it can do for him."
If you're a capable guy—looking for an action
job with rapid rewardsfor the man who can handle
it—you'll want to visit your Placement Office for
literature and additional information.

SC lips Standards
For Membership
On N-L Demands
The Student Council voted
this week to place itself under
the same academic requirements
as the executive officers of
other organizations. These requirements, however, were left
up in the air following a heated
discussion of the 2.3 minimum
average.
Which of three alternative
plans suggested by Dave Adams
was to constitute the final setup was forgotten as the Council
got itself into a heated discussion of the waiver power of the
Student Activities Commission.
The SAC is granted power to
waive candidates who do not
have a 2.3 average but whom
they consider in no danger of
failing and whom they consider
the "best" men for the jobs for
which they are running.
SAC Chairman Al Freeland
said that the SAC was given such
power to do a job that had to
be done by someone; that they
were the organization to do it;
and to say that their use of that
power was arbitrary was tantamount to calling last year's SAC
leaders dishonest.
alternatives
Adams' three
were (1) a strict 2.3 for everybody with no exception; (2) a 2.3
for the semester previous to the
boy's candidacy; or (3) a sliding
academic scale; freshman, 2.3;
sophomores, 2.2; juniors, 2.1.
Proponent for a 2.3 with no
exceptions, or simply a lower
required average—was Chips
Lickson. The SAC Chairman
argued for the status quo, however, saying that the present setup was fairest one for all concerned.

Head Librarian in the Main

Hubbard, stated, "We already
have so many books that there
is no room left on the shelves.

around, it is impossible to keep
track of the location of some
books, and the heads of departments are forced to keep the
new locations in their heads.
The crowded and dirty condition of the present library are
enough to eliminate even the
very hope of efficiency, and the
arrival of every new book creates
new problems and new frustration."

new quarters for the Library:

philosophy of education. The

Baltimore Poll Decides
Kennedy Big Hit OnTV
A presidential poll was taken
In this city by the Social Relations Department of Johns
Hopkins under the direction of
Dr. James Coleman. The purPose of this poll was to see how
the televised convention and debates had affected the people's
thinking.
The actual polling was done
by telephone. Eight hundred
People in the Baltimore area
Were called at three different
times during the year. ,
The first call was made in
early June before the nominating conventions. At this time
28.0% favored Nixon, 49.0%
Kennedy, and 23.0% • were undetided. In the last wek of August,
after the Republican convention,
the same people were called. At
this time 3.3% of the "unde-

NEW LIBRARY

cided" switched to Nixon. This
may have been due to the fact
that the Republican convention
was fresh in the minds of the
people, and they were impressed
with Nixon's speech.
The last phase of the poll was
taken after the second KennedyNixon debate, and this found a
switch of 3.2% of the previously
undecided to Kennedy.
Because Baltimore is a naturally Democratic city, these
percentages are not a valid indication of the trends in the
country, but the trend in the
undecided vote may very well
be an indication of the trends
in the country.

director of Public Relations for
the University, stated that at its
peak "File 7" was carried by 95
stations throughout the country.
Fewer Stations
But by the first week in September, when the last program
was shown, there were less than
thirty stations carrying the series, Mr. Poole added.
During the first years of its
run "File 7" was the only show
of its kind because stations did
not have the trained staffs necessary to produce such a program.
But over the years stations acquired these staffs.
"Each station has a public
service to perform for the community," Mr. Poole stated, "but
there is only a limited amount
of time it has to give for such
public service programs.
Local Interests
"Because of these factors more
and more local stations presented
public service programs from
local colleges and universities.
When they did this, they dropped
'File 7.'
"Comparing the 200 manhours required for every half
hour program, we found that we
were not getting a return for the
time invested."

be submitted in writing, signed,
to the Admissions Office.

In Memoriam
It was the longest running regularly scheduled program on television; for twelve years it amazed, informed,
taught, explained, and pioneered; it carried the name of
The Johns Hopkins University into millions upon millions
of homes; it brought Lynn Poole into the chair of producer, director, actor, and wr'iter ; it was all these things,
and many more, but it's all over—Johns Hopkins File 7
has closed shop.
Pressed by that economic law of diminishing returns,
File 7 saw itself being shelved all over the country lately
to make way for local interest educational programs. It
was becoming harder and harder for professors and
teachers to spare the time to help produce the kind of
quality shows typical to File 7.
If it be so, let this be a black and white memorial to
a fine job, well done. We are quite sure that this same
feeling is echoed by all those who grabbed the spark
offered to them by the program, and with it lighted the
tamp of higher learning.
There have been many 'thrilling' experiences connected with the program, but for Lynn Poole his proudest
was the year that freshmen avidly recalled the Hopkins
program, and the interest it generated, from their gradeschool days.

One Down—Two To Go
The Student Council jumped over the 2.3 minimum
average at its meeting this week, and landed on a significant motion: that members of the Student Council will be
subject to the same academic requirements as the executives of all other Hopkins organizations. In effect, this
means, assuming the 2.3 is retained, that just to be a
member of the council a man must hold an average of 2.3
—required of the officers of all other organizations, but
not of their members. A good step in the right direction!
Next: the 2.3 average—to keep in its present form
or to alter it; then: the enforcement of the requirement,
a problem which will bring in the questions of "waivers"
and whether the SAC is the proper organization to grant
them.

Ilue Key
The Director of Admissions at Johns Hopkins University, Robert Bilgrave, cites the example of the "topnotch physics student who almost came to Hopkins." He
visited JHU one day, received his interview, then was
handed a map of the campus and sent on his way. He
also visited M.I.T. There he was met by some of that
school's undergraduates who gave him a tour, answered
his questions, and made him feel completely welcome—
and wanted. Though prior to his trips he had indicated
preference for Hopkins, he wound at M.I.T.

German Music At Levering
Delta Phi Alpha, the German
honor society on the Johns
Hopkins campus, inaugurated its
activities of the year on Tuesday evening with a recorded
concert of German vocal music
from medieval times through
Bach. The concert was held at
Levering Hall and was in coordination with the German
club at Goucher College. This is
the first in a series of three
concerts in three consecutive
weeks that will attempt to trace
the development of the German
tongue through music. Next
Tuesday, the concert will include
the vocal music of the- classic
and romantic German composers. The third concert will
be devoted to late romantic
leider through the works of
Schoenberg,
Hindemith
and
modern German Composers.
Tuesday evening's concert began with a medieval song withaccompaniment,
iated
out
about the 12th century. Mark
Perel, who directed the program,
explained how German vocal
music before Bach reached its

peak with the works of Heinrich
Schurz in 1585. Schurz, who
studied with Monteverdi in Italy,
brought to German music many
of the complexities of Italian
baroque music, which was already well advanced for its time.
The program concluded with a
cross-section of the vocal music
of Bach, "the pinnacle of the
baroque." Excerpts included two
baritone arias from Cantata's
no. 8 and 82 and a portion of St.
Mathew's Passion.
To this listener who knows no
German and simply listens to
music for pleasure, the program
was very enjoyable. The music,
chosen seemed quite appropriate. Not only did it illustrate
the evolution of medieval German music, it was also very
pleasing to the ear. Anyone with
an interest in classical German
music will probably find the next
two concerts much to his liking.
Next week the program will feature music of, Beethoven and
Mozart. Delta Phi Alpha cordially invites all those interested to
attend the next two concerts.

By MIKE KOPPISCH
This year's freshman play,
"Love Rides the Rails," was an
abrupt departure from plays of
this sort presented in the past.
This comedy-melodrama-audience participation fiasco, under
the direction of Nick Bonacker
and Dennis Donahue, provided
the audience with as much oppOrtunity to display its talent
as it did the actors. In fact,
there were several cries from
the pit which met with as much
approval as certain parts of the
actual production.
As for talent, this reviewer is
forced to take the side of the
villains. Of course, it must also
be considered that these characterizations lent themselves to
humor much more readily than
those of the fair Prudence Hopewell and the "dry" Truman
Pendennis. Peter Grossman, who
played the moustached, caped
villain, Simon Darkway, carried out his role in a classic
manner. However, whether or
not he inspired any hate in the
audience is a matter left open to
debate. His "ever-scratching"
and imbecilic stooge Dirk Sneath
was very ably portrayed by Ed
Shiller.
Nancy Monroe as the ingenuous Miss Prudence Hopewell
evoked much applause from the
audience when, in the end of
the play, she was forced to remove her skirt and reveal her
bloomers in the presence of
gentlemen. The widow Hopewell
was also well characterized by
Barbara MacNamara. She provided much audience participation in the form of an "Amen"
after every mention of her dear
departed husband—Amen.
I found Joanne Winks' performance as the seductive Carlotta
Cortez very convincing. The
milk-sop, Truman Pendennis
and his naive playmate, Harold
Standfast, played by David
Munro and John Gunderson respectively, were not as convincing as they might have been.
A word must also be said for
David Hegen, who was responsible for the melodious tones
which emanated from a piano
which, I hope, has seen better
days. Many people do not realize
the true importance of music to
a show such as this. Without
musical accompaniment, this
show's success would have been
in possible jeopardy.
The purpose of the freshmen
play has always been to heighten spirit within the class. It has
therefore never been a serious
venture and should not be regarded as such. From the reaction of the audience, I would
say that this goal was fairly
well achieved.

"HOME SWEET HOMECOMING"
A great number of people have been asking me lately, "What
Is Homecoming?" but I have been so busy trying to find out
why my new sports car leaks that I haven't had time to answer.
I am now pleased to report that I finally discovered why my
sports car leaks—I have been driving it upside down—and so
I am ready today to turn my attention to Homecoming.
Let's begin with definitions. Homecoming is a weekend when
old grads return to their alma maters to watch a football game,
visit old classrooms and dormitories and inspect each other's
bald spots.
The weekend is marked by the singing of old songs, the slapping of old backs and the frequent exchange of such greetings
as "Harry,'you old polecat!" or "Harry, you old porcupine!"
or "Harry, you old rooster!" or "Harry, you old wombat!"
As you can see, all old grads are named Harry.
It is not just old grads who behave with such liveliness during
Homecoming; the faculty also comports itself with unaccustomed animation. Teachers laugh and smile and pound backs
and keep shouting "Harry,you old Airedale!" This unscholarly
behavior is carried on in the hope that old grads, in a transport
of bonhomie will endow a new geology building.
The old grads, however; are seldom seduced. By game time
on Saturday their backs are so sore, their eyeballs so eroded,
their extremities so frayed, that it is impossible to get a kind
word out of them, much less a new geology building.

Even the football game does not improve their tempers.
!'llmmph!" they snort as the home team completes a 101-yard
march to a touchdown."Do you call that football? Why, back
in my day, they'd have been over on the first down! By
George, football was football in those days—not this nambypamby girls' game that passes for football today! Take a look
at that bench-50 substitutes sitting there. Why, in my day,
there were 11 men on a team and that was it. When you broke
a leg, they slapped a piece of tape on it and you went right back
in. Why, I remember the big game against State. Harry Sigafoos, our star quarterback, was killed in the third quarter. I
mean, he was pronounced dead. But did that stop old Harry?
Not on your tintype! Back in he went and kicked the winning
drop kick in the last four seconds of play, dead as he was. Back
in my day, they played football, by George!"
Everything,say the old grads, was better back in their day—
everything except one. Even the most unreconstructed of the
old grads has to admit that back in his day they never had a
smoke like Marlboro—never a cigarette with such a lot to like
—never a filter so easy drawing, a flavor so mild yet hearty, so
abundant, so bountiful—never a choice of flip-top box or soft
pack.
So old grads, young grads, and undergrads, why don't you
settle back and have a full-flavored smoke? Try Marlboro, the
filtered cigarette with the unfiltered taste, and Homecoming
will be a happy occasion and the sun will shine and the air will
be filled with the murmur of wings and no man's hand will be
raised against you.

NAME: John Hulse AGE: 27 MAJOR: Bus. Adm.'
PRESENT JOB: Telephone Manager, Sioux City,Iowa
When John Hulse was a senior at the U. of
South Dakota, he had his own set of "do's" and
"don'ts." Don't become a mere cipher on somebody's payroll. Don't sit on the shelf waiting for
your first taste of responsibility. Do get a job
where you have a chance to show your stuff
right from the start. Do the job.
John knew his B.S. in Business Administration could lead him into almost any field. He
chose the telephone business and joined Northwestern Bell.
One of his first assignments: streamlining operating procedures for the telephone offices of Iowa's
five largest cities. In this work John showed
good judgment and sound organizing ability.
Today he is Telephone Manager of Sioux
City, Iowa.

Besides managing day-to-day operations,
helping plan tomorrow's telephone growth is
an important part of John's job. A typical example is the work he does with the Sioux City
Industrial Development Association. In this role,
he's the answer man on projecting, planning and
supplying the communications needs of new industry. He's shown above with Bob Sweeney,
manager of the Sioux City Chamber of Commerce.
"You must always be thinking of the future
in this business," John says. "We have to stay
ahead. I think a man who has something to offer
this outfit won't have a minute's worry about
what it can do for him."
If you're a capable guy—looking for an action
job with rapid rewardsfor the man who can handle
it—you'll want to visit your Placement Office for
literature and additional information.

The Student Council voted
this week to place itself under
the same academic requirements
as the executive officers of
other organizations. These requirements, however, were left
up in the air following a heated
discussion of the 2.3 minimum
average.
Which of three alternative
plans suggested by Dave Adams
was to constitute the final setup was forgotten as the Council
got itself into a heated discussion of the waiver power of the
Student Activities Commission.
The SAC is granted power to
waive candidates who do not
have a 2.3 average but whom
they consider in no danger of
failing and whom they consider
the "best" men for the jobs for
which they are running.
SAC Chairman Al Freeland
said that the SAC was given such
power to do a job that had to
be done by someone; that they
were the organization to do it;
and to say that their use of that
power was arbitrary was tantamount to calling last year's SAC
leaders dishonest.
alternatives
Adams' three
were (1) a strict 2.3 for everybody with no exception; (2) a 2.3
for the semester previous to the
boy's candidacy; or (3) a sliding
academic scale; freshman, 2.3;
sophomores, 2.2; juniors, 2.1.
Proponent for a 2.3 with no
exceptions, or simply a lower
required average—was Chips
Lickson. The SAC Chairman
argued for the status quo, however, saying that the present setup was fairest one for all concerned.

Bill Katz was elected chairman of the Freshman Spirit
Committee in a meeting last
Jim
Wednesday. Runner-up
easagrande was chosen as an
asistant to Katz after a suggestion by interim coordinator
David Adams. All sixteen of the
orientation groups were represented at this meeting.

The News-Letter has won 3
college
national
journalism
awards in a contest conducted
by Pi Delta Epsilon, the National Honorary Journalism Fraternity.
According to Dr. Robert C.
Wright of Mankato State College, director of the contest,
Pete Kivic, last years Contributing Editor, won a second place
in the news story contest. The
award was for Kivic's article on
local
discrimination
against
restaurants in local restaurants
and lunch counters.
An honorable mention in the
same category went to editor-

in-chief Niels F. Sundermeyer
for his story on the proposed
purchase of Wyman Park by
the university
Co-editors Handmaker and
Sundermeyer garnered a third
place in the editorial division
for their front page effort
against discrimination.

The following was printed in
the McDonogh School newspaper,
The Week, on November 13, 1959.

AD LIB
A certain Middle School housemaster must not think highly
of his "holding power" for the
boys in his charge. Perhaps, too,
he believes that "forewarned is
forearmed" and is attempting to
gather information to enable him
to be a more efficient warden.
Escape Plan
In any event, this English
teacher, who should, but undoubtedly won't, remain forever
nameless, assigned his students
to write compositions on "How
to Escape from McDonogh."
This same fine teacher was
written up in The Sunday Sun as
a typical example of the Master
of Arts Program at Johns Hopkins University. He is quoted as
having stated that, probably because he gave his students more
work than they received from
any three other teachers, they
found at least three ways to refer
to him—Barta, Bartall, and
Bartuh.

A revival of record concerts
and an initiation of a series of
informal coffee-hour discussions
head a list of activities to be
sponsored by the Levering Hall
YMCA this year.
Suspended last year, the concerts provide an opportunity for
all those desiring to hear good
music to do so at noon in Levering Hall. Programs will be posted
in advance, and persons with
suggestions or criticism are invited to leave them at the "Y"
office.
Featuring Owen Lattimore, of

the department of history, whose
topic will be "The New Asia," the
"Y" will begin its informal talks
October 27, in the Sherwood
Room at 4:00. Additional speakers from on and off campus will
appear in this series which is to
consider questions of current interest. All interested persons are
invited to come and partake of
free coffee and talk with the
speakers.
